isis.stitle: New Vehicle Processing Manual - CF 500, CF 600 Heat Ventilation Air Conditioning (HVAC) System - SERVICE PROCEDURES - EVACUATING THE SYSTEM

svcproc.title: EVACUATING THE SYSTEM

warning.para: Before doing any of the work below, read the SERVICE WARNINGS. Failure to read the Service Warnings and to be aware of the dangers involved when working with refrigerant could lead to serious personal injury.

caution.para: The amount of oil lost during the recovery process, component replacement, or purging/flushing must be replaced with new oil. The method for determining how much refrigerant oil must be added to the A/C system is located in the OIL FILL GUIDELINES.

Use only the specified PAG lubricant in the refrigerant system. PAG oils absorb atmospheric moisture very quickly. Never leave PAG oil exposed to air for a prolonged time. Tightly reseal the oil container immediately after each use.
Do not re-use recovered oil. Be sure to dispose of recovered oil properly to avoid an environmental hazard.

important.para: Although your service equipment may appear physically different from the equipment shown here, the function of the equipment used to perform each service procedure is basically the same. If you are performing these service procedures using service equipment different from that shown, refer to the manufacturer's instructions supplied with that equipment.

svcproc.para: Whenever the air conditioning system has been discharged, the system must be completely evacuated of air and moisture before being recharged. After evacuation the system vacuum should read at least 99.4 kPa (29.5 in-Hg) and as close to 101.1 kPa (30 in-Hg) as possible, when using analog gauges. If the electronic vacuum gauge is used the vacuum in the evacuated system should measure between 750 and 1000 microns.

step1.para: Determine the amount of NEW refrigerant oil to be added to the system. Refer to OIL FILL GUIDELINES. If oil is being added directly to the compressor, it must be added before starting the evacuation procedure. If oil is to be added during the evacuation/charging procedure, you must follow the instructions furnished with the recovery station, or refrigerant oil injector tool, to add the oil before the charging procedure.

On the recovery station and hose fittings, verify that all valves are closed. The valves at the recovery station must be set to the CLOSED position. The valves at the quick-disconnect fittings must be set fully counter-clockwise (CCW).
If the electronic vacuum gauge is being used, connect it to the recovery station vacuum manifold, using a valve and 'T' fittings.

figure.caption: Figure 4. Connection of Electronic Vacuum Gauge

caution.para: The valve for the electronic vacuum gauge must be in the closed position until instructed to open it. If the valve is open during system charging, excess pressure may damage the electronic vacuum gauge.

step1.para: Connect the recovery station to the system as follows:

step2.para: Start with the blue low pressure hose, and connect it to the low pressure service port located on the compressor manifold and tube near the evaporator fitting.
Connect the red hose to the high pressure service port located on the receiver/drier.

step1.para: On the red and blue hoses, open the valves on the Metric SAE quick-disconnect fittings (turn the knobs fully CW).
On the recovery station, set both hand valves to the RECOVERY/VACUUM position.
On the recovery station, turn on main power switch and press the VACUUM button (turns vacuum pump on).
After the low pressure gauge reads at least 99.4 kPa (29.5 in-Hg), continue to operate the vacuum pump for ten minutes.
After ten minutes, set both valves to the CLOSED position. If a manual vacuum pump is being used, turn off the pump.

Observe the low side gauge for one minute. The gauge should not indicate a rise of more than 2 inches-Hg. If the gauge rises more than 2 inches-Hg in one minute, the system has a leak which must be repaired. Refer to LEAK DETECTION.
If there are no leaks, and the electronic vacuum gauge IS being used:

step2.para: Set both hand valves on the recovery station to the RECOVERY/VACUUM position and press the VACUUM button.
Open the valve connecting the electronic vacuum gauge to the recovery station low side line.
Continue to operate the recovery station vacuum pump until the system has pulled a vacuum of 750 to 1000 microns as measured by the electronic vacuum gauge.
Close both hand valves on the recovery station, and the valve connecting the electronic vacuum gauge to the recovery station low side line.

step1.para: If there are no leaks, and the electronic vacuum gauge IS NOT being used:

step2.para: Open both hand valves and start the vacuum pump.
Once the vacuum reads at least 99.4 kPa (29.5 in-Hg), continue to operate the vacuum pump for a minimum of 45 minutes.
After 45 minutes, close both hand valves and turn off the vacuum pump.
The vacuum in the system must read at least 99.4 kPa (29.5 in-Hg) and as close to 101.1 kPa (30 in-Hg) as possible.

step1.para: The A/C system is ready to be charged. REMEMBER if the full amount of refrigerant oil has not yet been added to the system, it must be added before charging the system with refrigerant, as explained in the following procedure.

important.para: DO NOT disconnect the recovery/recycling/charging station from the A/C system before charging the system.
